2021-05-30.text: I believe it’s to do with dropping oestrogen levels. Oestrogen receptors interact with the dopamine system in our brains so it’s possible that less oestrogen = less effective dopamine 😊 did a whole dissertation on this 😅

I needed to up my dose after a few weeks, but I started on ritalin first. I like concerta as I get less side-effects and don't have to manage multiple doses, but I do need a short-release "booster" when it wears off in the afternoon.

Not until I was diagnosed and my fatigue massively improved on meds - the tiredness was a mystery I never thought would be solved! I did some more research on it for a blog post, and it's helped me recognise when I'm heading for a crash.

Usually doctors are more worried about your blood pressure going up on ADHD medication, so hopefully all will be fine. Some meds can also lower BP (such as guanfacine and clonidine), so they might be a good option for you!

2021-05-29.text: Our practical exams are still closed-book, but there’s no reason for knowledge tests to be - I have poor memory so was really disadvantaged by them. We do need a basic amount of facts remembered, but things like dosages, medications and tests are always safest when checked!

I’m a medical student, and we’re encouraged to look things up on the BNF and other websites when we’re unsure - it can only improve patient care, imo. 

This is also why I believe in open-book exams in med school.

Thank you for this thread! I’m definitely going through a process of becoming “un-masked Catriona” who I didn’t even realise existed until I was diagnosed and started to recognise my own behaviours I was using to “fit in” with others.
Ah that makes sense, thank you for answering! I think I’ll add an abbreviations section to the FAQ on my blog - mostly for my own learning to be honest, I’m terrible at working out acronyms 😂

2021-05-28.text: The one phrase I like to remind myself of when I’m not feeling too confident taking things at my own pace, is “slow and steady wins the race”! Better to move slowly than not at all ❤️
This is why I’m a big advocate for both online / offline learning options, and more importantly, the ability to choose.
What does amab mean, if you don’t mind me asking? 😊

I was an inconsistent hard worker who always crammed to just manage the grades I needed on results day.... until I got to med school at 18, when no amount of effort (+ burnout) could get me the grades I needed. After 18 months struggling, I was diagnosed with #ADHD. 

#GetInflow https://t.co/6HPVHOmVxj
Thank you so so much for those recommendations!! ❤️
The amount of blood tests I had followed by being told I just wasn’t getting enough sleep or trying hard enough to stay awake... it doesn’t take long to blame yourself!

Yes to this - I’m 50% of the way towards being a doctor, and I’m really embarrassed by how volatile my emotions are, and how I can lose every possession instantly. Sometimes, when I’m feeling particularly ashamed, I wonder whether I’m capable of being trusted with patients...

This is SO frustrating! It was frustrating researching my diagnosis, but even more so researching my diagnosis - adult women get #ADHD too, and there isn’t a magical ‘coping manual’ you’re given on your 18th birthday!

Interestingly, my mum has only worked out that she may have #ADHD now that my younger brother and I have been diagnosed with it. She used to say “that’s normal, I always used to do that when I was your age” a lot.... no more 😅 #GetInflow https://t.co/sziJxdj35W

The more I get to grips with my ADHD diagnosis, the more I realise that 20% of the negative judgement comes from others, and the rest comes from myself... I’m really keen to learn how to reframe it and treat myself more kindly!
This is why I’ve started my own blog - as much as I like writing for other sources, often I don’t want to fit my story into another context to ensure it gets published.

As someone paying £250 for a 15 minute phone call just to repeat my stimulant prescription... it’s very expensive to have a disability like #ADHD 😣

#GetInFlow https://t.co/VF0GYYGt7A
When I don’t take my meds, I fall asleep for hours at a time from overstimulation... hyperactive is only 10% max of my #ADHD.... #getinflow https://t.co/CWuhPsGixl

I had an article in a national newspaper yesterday about having ADHD as a medical student, and have worried that it’s doing harm to my career and not actually helping anyone - reading this has really eased off the anxiety and I feel slightly less vulnerable, so thank you ❤️
Agreed - I love hyperfocusing. It helped me build my website from scratch yesterday! On days like that, my #ADHD brain only feels like a positive. #GetInFlow

This is always hard to explain to others - why a single, unexpected disappointment can really upset me. Just going to the supermarket takes a lot more ‘social energy’ than it does those who are neurotypical. #GetInFlow https://t.co/8KrNTH2lrv

Massively agree with this. 10% of the improvement of my quality life post-diagnosis came from meds, the other 90% came from finally knowing, researching and understanding why I’m the way I am. It’s done wonders for my self-esteem and ability to function.

ADHD is my superpower is fine until it burns you out... which doesn’t take me very long. Seeing the positives of your #ADHD and ignoring the negatives are two very different things...
#GetInflow https://t.co/GdIKiuOsxX

Stop stereotyping, and start actively challenging misconceptions. Start presenting positive #ADHD role models. In ‘real’ life, I know very few medics who are open about their ADHD and it definitely impacts how I feel about it. #GetInFlow https://t.co/IFAiWeYIEe
I found CBT impossible until I started meds. Can’t just not overthink or ruminate when it’s what your brain is chemically wired to do... #GetInFlow #ADHD https://t.co/zcu0HbZJvB

SO much of the content about ADHD online is aimed at parents of children with ADHD. We need more aimed at adults with ADHD, and women, and those in medical work settings where stigma and stereotypes are still pervasive. Hence creating a certain blog... #GetInFlow https://t.co/ntDXnhLvMl

Not all of us are hyperactive all the time! I’m 10% hyperactive, the rest of the time I fall asleep for multi-hour naps because of overstimulation ... this can be really hard to explain to other medical students. It’s not laziness or lack of sleep!

Proud to share a piece that I’ve written for  about improving support for NHS staff with mental health conditions, as a medical student with #ADHD. 

#ADHDtwitter #MedTwitter https://t.co/gJ6H9ThTX7

2021-05-26.text: Oh my god it’s a thing!! I thought it was just me.... so many texts sent

Now I’ve got my mental health to a good place, I’ve found that I have no tolerance for voluntary stress (ie from things I’ve chosen to do) anymore.

Having struggled with anxiety for so long, I don’t know if that’s a good thing or not. Is this ‘normal’? 😅

#askADHD any thoughts?

2021-05-25.text: Congrats! This is exactly how I felt as well - it gets less “euphoric” after a while, but the focus remains 😊

I’m interested to know how others manage taking meds through the day - I usually forget until I have a crash once my first dose has worn off.... 

I’m also nervous to be taking them into hospital for placement every day from September, and ensuring I get breaks to take them.
That’s great that you can send questions like that!
Yep, very happy on my stimulants and they’ve saved my degree, but I still can’t keep track of any of my belongings!

2021-05-21.text:
On one of the BMA committees I sit on, we try to start email subjects with “to note”, “action” or “feedback required”.

I also love it when people finish a message with a TL;DR and a list of action points.

It makes sorting through emails so much easier!

#adhdtwitter #ADHD https://t.co/nAfjo8j5CG

Ritalin suppressed my appetite but I didn’t lose any weight as I still boredom-snacked. Started an SSRI in Feb and have 100% unintentionally lost 7kg, as I just don’t need the dopamine / serotonin from mindless eating anymore
Prioritising post-exam relaxation... and not feeling guilty about it!

2021-05-20.text: I have never heard of that, or at least I’ve never read about it in the DSM!
My boyfriend sometimes signals to me discretely when I’m on a tangent, which can help, unless I’m feeling anxious that day - then it just makes me feel guilty 😅
Not the most flattering pic, but this is me chatting at a ball in 2020 - thankfully with two friends who were very used to my talking speed by that point!

New post today, about "excessive" talking in #ADHD.

I have really mixed feelings about this, as yes we need to be considerate to others, but I don't think we should have to suppress who we are either.

What do you think?

2021-05-07.text: I get this! Definitely some form of auditory processing problem... might have to do a Google scholar info search later 😬
Mine definitely was until I started meds. It really shocked me that my brain could feel clear, because it never had before.

2021-05-05.text: Find what works for you, and don’t ever be made to feel ashamed or guilty for accommodations - you have every right to the same opportunities as everyone else.
Gosh I related to so much of this - especially the exhaustion and naps! I used to never attend lectures, and would fall into a deep sleep for 4 hours every afternoon...

Still trying to work this out! I can’t do super long study days like some medics can, so I’m trying to accept that a productive 2 hours at my desk is better than a semi-productive 8 hours followed by burnout - comparison with others is a big struggle though...
Yep - when I interrupt others I feel like the worst person in the world, especially when I can tell it’s annoying them

These should be things we want in academics, not reasons to push people out... medicine is getting *slightly* better, but there’s still too much encouragement of unhealthy ways of working and living. A better culture will benefit us all.

Brief break from #adhdtwitter thanks to an emergency hospital admission and wisdom tooth removal... but back now!!

My exams are next week, and I’m feeling a bit guilty about not being able to study like I’d planned - any tips (or reassurance)? 😅

#askADHD #medstudenttwitter https://t.co/dF9Ecckxsa

Hello! Taking antidepressants is absolutely not a problem, as long as you disclose it when asked. They’re simply checking for things they can support you with if needed. I’m a UK med student, and take ADHD meds and an antidepressant 😊

Out of sight, out of mind - problems with working memory (often mistaken for object permanence) are central to a lot of the frustrations of having #ADHD.

What are your top tips for living with a poor working memory?

#askADHD #ADHDtwitter https://t.co/JSaBLFb7KO

Definitely agree with this - the encouragement of a poor work-life balance doesn’t benefit anyone, ADHD or not, in my experience. Med schools need to set an example early on in our careers before bad habits get too ingrained and become the ‘standard’.

Planning some content...

2021-04-26.text: Before I hit the right combo of meds, I’d sometimes tear up or feel annoyed, but not be able to explain why. I knew I wasn’t happy with something... just not what 🤔

’s experience made me write a bit of a rant about this - you can have an SpLD and be successful!! 
I’m a medical student so not doing too badly, but feel I have to work twice as hard for the same results - burnout in the past has been immense. 

https://t.co/QVZb9ADLUM
A long nap is my favourite indulgence - sorts out any and all problems in my opinion, from feeling poorly to a bad mood! 😂

I've always had a problem with interrupting people while they’re talking – or jumping in the exact millisecond they finish speaking!

Why do people with #ADHD interrupt others? Can we control it, or are we just rude?

Read more here: https://t.co/dmPh3WUOLy

#adhdtwitter #askADHD https://t.co/laoi8cZDm4

Fatigue can actually be a sign of #ADHD, and it's more common than you think.

#adhdtwitter + #askADHD - how does ADHD affect your energy levels? Is it just me that's susceptible to a 4 hour "power nap"? https://t.co/PmUwNrgkVC

How do I organise my life as a medical student with #ADHD?

Featuring  and my 3 other favourite tools... 

https://t.co/WnFncz5yRm 

#adhdtwitter #MedStudentTwitter

Break it into chunks, put the chunks into a to-do list, and decide on a reward for every time you get a chunk done - also decide which days you’d like to do each chunk so you don’t procrastinate it, but don’t be too strict with it. This was how I got my dissertation done 😊

#ADHD procrastination is related to our difficulties regulating thoughts and emotions. 

This is why telling us to “just do it” can be likened to telling someone with clinical depression to “just cheer up”.

Read more here: https://t.co/LbbK8z1tGH

#ADHDtwitter https://t.co/kUgFqbnu3l
